result.markdown:
--- title: "Dynasties of wealth:
The preservation of wealth within families" author: "Daria Tisch

9 April 2025


Max Planck Institute for the Study of Societies
" subtitle: "Institute Seminar" format: revealjs: theme: [default, custom.scss] preview-links: auto chalkboard: boardmarker-width: 5 title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: "images/Designer.jpeg" data-background-size: "cover" # or "contain" data-background-opacity: "0.2" # adjust transparency data-background-position: "center" gfm: mermaid-format: svg editor: visual slide-number: c #https://quarto.org/docs/publishing/github-pages.html#render-to-docs bibliography: references.bib --- # Imagine the 1000 richest people in Germany in 1913. How many of them do you think have descendants who are on the rich list today? ## Motivation ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](images/pyramide.webp) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - High levels of wealth inequality[@piketty2014] - Wealth is highly concentrated in the hands of a **few families** - Small group with disproportionate amount of political and economic power and social influence ::: ::::: ## Research questions in my projects - Who are the superrich? - How much social mobility is there within the wealth elite? - What are the mechanisms of wealth perpetuation? - What is the **role of the family** in wealth concentration? ## Overview of research projects ![](images/overview.png) ::: notes - iuse different data sources to understand the role of the family in wealth perpetuation - first, i use tax data to better understand transfer behavior of the wealthy. I show gender differences (men prefer sons in their gift behavior) and show that one-third of estates are made unequally between siblings - second, i use rich lists ::: ## Dynasties of wealth: The preservation of wealth within families {.smaller} ::: {style="font-size: 120%"} **How do families manage to maintain their position at the top of the wealth distribution over more than a century?** ::: ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} [So what?]{style="color:#8B0000;font-size: 120%"} - Mobility within the wealt elite? "each class resembles a hotel \[...\] always full, but always of different people" [@schumpeter1972] - Normative: Performance and not birth should influence wealth position - Social cohesion at risk [@toft2022] - Social background of wealth elite matters for politics we get [@reeves2024] ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](images/hotel2-01.webp) ::: ::::: ::: notes - Larger project describing the super-rich in Germany - Article 1: Today's super-rich - Historical projects, wealth accumulated partly over several generations - New project: how families manage to maintain their position at the top of the wealth distribution over more than 100 years. I am interested in the influence of social structure and in particular how family relationships and membership of the aristocracy contribute to the preservation of wealth. - Why is it relevant to look at whether and how the wealth elite maintains its position over a century? - 1. to understand the role of the family as an economic unit. Does the family play a relevant role in the (re)production of wealth and the wealth elite? - 2. normative justification. Meritocracy: merit, not birth, determines position in wealth distribution. - 3.economic resources distributed inefficiently. no personal change within the elite--\> social closure--\> no longer understands social problems and thus jeopardises social cohesion. ::: ## Previous research {.smaller} - Family as a relevant economic unit [@farrell1993a] - Intergenerational wealth mobility low [@hansen2014; @clark2015; @pfeffer2018; @hällsten2023; @toft2022] - Despite institutional changes: Wealth mobility constant in GB (1858-2012) [@clark2015] - Persistence in wealth, income and elite occupations in Italy [@barone2020] - Germany: About 8% of today's 1000 largest fortunes can be traced back to fortunes from the 1913 wealth lists [@tisch2023] - Zurich: About 20% of 1952' top 0.1% have ancestors within top 0.1% in 1890, yearly survival rate of 97.5% [@legentilhomme2023] → Research gap: Mechanisms of wealth preservation of families, e.g. family ties within the elite ::: notes What can we learn from previous research on wealth preservation? - Franziska Wiest: managing family feelings plays a critical role in wealth reproduction - Wealth mobility is low, especially at the upper and lower ends of the wealth distribution. - Register data (Norway) and survey data (up to three generations). - Rare surnames to estimate wealth mobility over several generations or even centuries. - Clark & Cummins look at wealth mobility in the UK and show that it has remained constant over the last 5 generations despite institutional changes. \[When he groups surnames by wealth level, there is less mobility than when he looks at individual surnames\] - Barone & Mocetti look at the city of Florence and show an enormous persistence in income, wealth and elite occupations between 1427 and 2011. But what are the socio-structural mechanisms of wealth preservation? My contribution: 1. to what extent is there social mobility within the wealth elite in Germany? 2. explain the persistence of wealth through socio-structural factors. 3. family ties within the wealth and political elite 4. by looking at the connection between the wealth elite and the political elite, I also contribute to one of the most important topics of elite literature, namely whether there was a homogeneous elite. 5. shifting the perspective to kinship structures as social groups, where social reproduction works at the group level, appears to be a fruitful endeavor, and it should be a future aim to identify more kin group-level characteristics that explain persistence. (Hällsten und Kolk 2020) ::: ## Reproduction of the wealth elite {.smaller} - Family as a central institution for the reproduction of social inequality [@beckert2022; @wiest2025; @mare2011; @obrien2023; @pfeffer2018] - Reproduction of the wealth elite - Education [@lillie2020] - Direct intergenerational transfers - "Opportunity hoarding" [@tilly1998] - Social closure through marriage [@farrell1993] - Economic alliance building [@zeitlin1974] ![](images/Picture2.png) ::: notes ::: ## Hypotheses **Hypothesis 1: [Members of the economic elite are more likely to have descendants on today's rich list than non-members]{style="color:#8B0000"}** → Socialisation in business families and economic alliances [@augustine2003] **Hypothesis 2: [The more interconnected a rich individual is with other rich individuals through familial ties, the greater the likelihood their descendants will appear on today’s rich lists]{style="color:#8B0000"}** → Strategic family alliances to consolidate the social position [@augustine1994; @farrell1993; @zeitlin1974] **Hypothesis 3: [Members of the political elite are more likely to have descendants on today's rich list than non-members]{style="color:#8B0000"}** → Stealth politics [@page2018] ::: notes - Hypotheses - argument: strategic alliances are necessary to maintain the position at the top of the wealth distribution. - Good family network. Just as a good network is important for an individual to accumulate wealth over the course of their life, I expect that it is also important for families to have a good family network. - "imprinting effect" of belonging to the core of the elite. - Qualitative studies such as Betty Farrell's for Boston in the 19th century point to the importance of the family network. And I would like to look at whether a good family network at the beginning of the 20th century has long-term consequences. - What is the imprinting effect? Name? - The imprinting effect is a positive correlation between the level of wealth and the chances of wealth preservation. Charles Wright Mills argues in his book "The power elite" that wealth brings with it an accumulation advantage. The more strategic the economic position and the richer a person is, the easier it is to accumulate even more wealth: "The more he has, the greater his credit" ::: # Data and methods ## Data basis {.scrollable} ::::: columns ::: {.column width="30%"} ![](images/martin.png){.absolute top="100" left="0" width="270"} ::: ::: {.column width="70%"} - Jahrbuch des Vermögens und Einkommens der Millionäre [@martin1912; @gajek2014] - Database of members of the Reichstag (1867 - 1938) [^1] - *List of members of the Prussian House of Lords* [^2] - *List of members of the Prussian House of Representatives [@mann1998]* - Today's Manager Magazin lists (Bornefeld 2019) - Wikidata ::: ::::: [^1]: https://www.reichstag-abgeordnetendatenbank.de/ [^2]: https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liste_der_Mitglieder_des_Preu%C3%9Fischen_Herrenhauses ::: notes The yearbook of the wealth and income of billionaires by Rudolf Martin (Prussia) serves as my data basis. - How to get in touch with Rudolf Martin - Manager Magazin - Verknüpfung wie? - Explain Wikidata ::: ## Data and methods {.smaller} - Data - Rudolf Martin rich list, 1913 - \>2 Mio: N = 4574 richest individuals (top 0.007% of the population) - **\>3 Mio: N = 2520 richest individuals (top 0.003% of population)** - Variables: - still rich today (Manager Magazin List 2019, top 0.01%) - Politician or related to politician (members of parliament) - Part of the economic elite (Windolf und Marx) - Closeness and eigen centrality (geneological Wikidata) - Methods - Network analyses - Regression analyses ::: notes For the network analysis, I linked the data set of the rich and the data set of the politicians with Wikidata and scraped all direct relatives. To test my hypotheses, I run logistic regressions, since my dependent variable is binary. Population 1913: 67 million today, germany: 42 million: top 1031 fortunes --\> 4000 households: 0.01% ::: ## Wikidata ![](images/wikidata_bertha_bild.png){.absolute top="100" left="0" width="70%"} ![](images/wikidata_bertha.png){.absolute top="50" left="350" width="50%"} ## Wikidata: Bertha Krupp [Bertha Krupp](https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q66505) ::: notes - show different example quieries in the wikidata querie service - occupation of Father of father of Bill Gates ::: # Findings ## Social mobility within the wealth elite
| Individuals 1913 | Proportion of rich descendants | |---------------------------------|--------------------------------| | Wealth \>= 6 Mio (N = 884) | 10% | | Wealth \>= 5.5 Mio (N = 1135) | 9% | | **Wealth \>= 3 Mio (N = 2520)** | **6%** | | Wealth \>= 2 Mio (N = 4574) | 5% | ## Family network analysis - 975 individuals with Wikidata ID, from 2520 (wealth\>=3 Mio) (39%) - 411 rich individuals with at least one relative in Wikidata - Largest family web includes 145 rich individuals (24 times as many as a random sample of German wikidata humans born in the same cohorts) ## Rich family networks ![](images/graph1.jpeg){.absolute top="50" left="0" width="100%"} ::: {style="position: absolute; top: 30%; left: 80%; transform: translate(-50%, -50%); color: white; background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5); padding: 10px; border-radius: 5px;"} (975 Wikidata, 411 relatives, 145 largest network) ::: ::: notes - 975 individuals with Wikidata ID, from 2520 (wealth\>=3 Mio) (39%) - 411 rich individuals with at least one relative in Wikidata - Largest family web includes 145 rich individuals (24 times as many as a random sample of German wikidata humans born in the same cohorts) ::: ## Random family network ![](images/graph_randomC.svg){.absolute top="50" left="0" width="100%"} ::: {style="position: absolute; top: 25%; left: 80%; transform: translate(-50%, -50%); color: white; background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5); padding: 10px; border-radius: 5px;"} (N = 975 random Germans, same cohort, 5-8 in largest network) ::: ## Regression results: Likelyhood to have descendants on todays's rich list ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](institute_seminar_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Geographical analyses: Cologne ## Geographical analyses: Hamburg ## Geographical analyses: Berlin ::: {.cell} ::: ## Regression analyses {.smaller} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
  M1 M2 M3
Predictors Odds Ratios Odds Ratios Odds Ratios
number of rich neighbors,
500m		 0.99 **
Nobility 2.20 ** 2.35 *** 2.35 ***
Business elite 2.24 ** 2.28 *** 2.27 ***
Log. wealth 2.69 *** 2.60 *** 2.65 ***
Male 0.45 ** 0.45 ** 0.44 **
has_rich_neighbors 0.89
>5 rich neighbors 0.69
Observations 2704 2704 2704
R2 Tjur 0.065 0.060 0.061
* p<0.05   ** p<0.01   *** p<0.001
````` ::: ::: ## Conclusion {.smaller} - Social mobility within the wealth elite - 10 % of the 875 richest people in 1913 have descendants on the rich list 2019 - „Hotel“ has some regular guests - Mechanisms of maintaining top wealth in the 20th century - Connections to the business elite - Family networks of the super-rich - Being Politican and rich neighborhood irrelevant? - Next steps - Regional political offices - Role of geographical connections: the good address \ ::: {style="font-size: 120%; text-align: center"} Contact: tisch\@mpifg.de dariatisch.github.io ::: ::: notes - 6% der 1000 reichsten Preußen haben Nachfahren haben, die heute noch auf der Reichenliste stehen. - Familie und familiäre Beziehungen Anfang des 20. Jahrhundert haben bedeutende Rolle gespielt - [@wagner2020; @toft2022] - Und dass die heutige Reichtums- und Sozialstruktur immer noch von familiären Netzwerken von vor über 100 Jahren geprägt sind. "imprinting effect" von damaliger Elite - Nicht die Zugehörigkeit zum Adel erklärt Vermögenserhalt, - Ist dieses Projekt erfolgsversprechend? Ich bin gerade erst am Anfang und an dem Punkt, ob ich Zeit in den weiteren Aufbau der Datenbank stecken soll: Klassifikation des Adels, Religion, regionale Politik, nicht nur Preußen sondern ausweiten auf andere Gebiete. Lohnt sich das? - - Dies verdeutlicht, dass die Betrachtung von Familien als soziale Gruppen wichtig ist, um soziale Reproduktion zu verstehen. Soziale Reproduktion auf Gruppenebene (Familie): Identifizierung von Familiencharakteristiken notwendig, um Reichtumserhalt zu erklären (Hällsten und Kolk 2020) - Datenanalyse mit Bankier sowie Unternehmer - Theorieteil: Wieso sollte Zugehörigkeit zur Machtelite langfristig Reichtumserhalt begünstigen? - "today's inequality regime may have been formed many generations back." (Wagner 2022) - shifting the perspective to kinship structures as social groups, where social reproduction works at the group level, appears to be a fruitful endeavor, and it should be a future aim to identify more kin group-level characteristics that explain persistence. (Hällsten und Kolk 2020) ::: # Appendix ## Regression analyses ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
